blocks.text: After retracing our route to Jacob Lake we this time head north toward the edge of the plateau once again, stop at the observation station shown above to secure the view below of the distant panorama of Utah.
A tree at the edge of the plateau has been twisted into a grotesque shape by the force of the elements.
In the desert again as we enter Utah in the early evening. We drive to Mt. Carmel Junc-tion, then head into Zion National Park via the Mt. Carmel Highway to spend the night in a cabin in the Park.

blocks.text: THIRTEENTH DAY — Thursday, July 2. Through Zion National Park, to Bryce Canyon National Park, state road #22 to regain R#89, north through central Utah as far as Provo. 6:30 A. M. to 7:30 P. M. 362 miles – total 3643 miles.

Zion National Park, located in the canyon country of southern Utah, has as its chief feature the tree-mendous gorge, fifteen miles long by one-half mile deep and one-half mile wide, known as Zion Canyon. This canyon has been cut over a period of millions of years by the Virgin River, leaving stratified sandstone cliffs in colors of dark red, orange, pink and white. Leading into the canyon from the east is the Zion-Mt. Carmel Highway, part of which is carved through solid rock, one of the outstanding drives in the world.
We entered the Park in late evening, spent the night in one of the Government-maintained cabins, and re-turneded the following morning, thus twice traveling the Zion-Mt. Carmel Highway.
The night spent in this Government-maintained cabin ($4.50 for all of us), the most western point reachable on, the mosst westemn point reachable on the enntire tripreeched on the enntire tripp.
Impressive entrance to Zion National Park.
The weirdly cracked expanse of stone just inside the east entrance to the Park.

blocks.text: The Great White Throne whose walls rise nearly half a mile straight into the air.
From the tunnel the road descends in an almost perfect hairpin curve to the canyon floor.
The awesome canyon of Zion is difficult to photograph in the early morning and late evening since the low-lying sun fails to cast its light down the steep walls.

blocks.text: CLEAR CREEK RANCH LODGE

Breakfast, finally after emerging from Zion,
at the Clear Creek Ranch Lodge.
Gas pump at Mt. Carmel Junction shown only because the price of gas is 37 3/10¢ per gallon, the highest price paid for gas on the entire trip.
We head for Bryce Canyon National Park, eighty-nine miles northeast of Zion.
Just before reaching Bryce Canyon we traverse Red Canyon, a preview of Bryce.

blocks.text: Bryce Canyon - "A magic wonderland of beauty unparalleled elsewhere on earth." Here black and white photography fails to convey the true essence of the scene, for the fantastic formations surge with color - pale pinks blending into rosy reds, tans, purples and creamy whites. It is the "Canyon of Fire"... an amphitheatre of sixteen square miles, 1,000 feet deep.

blocks.text: After Bryce, lunch at Ruby's Inn; then north well off the tourist route on a dirt road through a dark canyon to regain U. S. #89. The car is soon covered with dust. To the east is Escalante Country, named for the Spanish padre who explored the area at the time of the American Revolution. This area is de-scribed in the September, 1949 "National Geographic Magazine" as "...the last frontier in Utah, one of the least known wilderness areas in the United States."

The lush farming area of central Utah where the Mormon pioneers have made a desert bloom through irrigation. Water from the melting snows on the mounds is collected in large reservoirs, from which the water is gradually fed to the surrounding farms. The Mormon farmers employ a peculiar "lift" which is shown on three of the pictures. The traveler cannot help but be impressed by these prosperous farms lying in verdant valleys surrounded by barren mountains. A hardy, resourceful people, indeed.

blocks.text: A motel for the night as we enter Provo, a steel center of the west, includes two bedrooms, a bath and kitchen for $8.50. Mountains rise steeply in background.

FOURTEENTH DAY - Friday, July 3. Provo to Salt Lake City, to Logan, into Idaho at Bear Lake, to Montpelier, into Wyoming, follow Star Valley to Afton – short day to give full next day to Grand Teton and Yellowstone National Parks. 7:30 a.m. M. to 3:30 P. M. 255 miles - total 3898 miles.

blocks.text: Main street of Salt Lake City with the plush Hotel Utah at left.
The Heart of Mormonism showing the Brigham Young Monument and the great Mormon Temple which took forty years to build.

As we drive north from Salt Lake City, the Great Salt Lake shines very white in the distance to the west. The Lake 75 miles long by 50 miles wide is the largest inland body of salt water in the world. It has no known outlet. The water is about 23 per cent salt.
Mormon Temple at Logan as we head northeast through Utah. This is in the fertile Cache Valley.

blocks.text: Along the shore of Bear Lake we enter Idaho for a short drive through the southeastern corner of the state heading for Wyoming.
Wonderful Idaho, with its rolling uplands, where the air is so pure it feels good just to be alive.

blocks.text: In the entire state of Wyoming, 78 times the size of Rhode Island, there are only 213 settlements. Of these only 97 are lived in by more than 100 people, and only 3 towns have a population of more than...

After entering Wyoming we proceed up the Star Valley, a rich farm-ing and dairy land watered by the Salt River, only as far as Afton. We locate a motel at 3:30 P. M., an early hour by all previous days' comparison. We need a rest for we have traveled 2,150 miles in six days...and we realize we must have a jump-off spot close enough to the Grand Teton and Yellowstone National Parks to complete our visit in one day, that day being the 4th of July when accommodations would be at a premium.

blocks.text: TWELFTH DAY — Wednesday, July 1. Joseph City, Arizona west almost to Flagstaff, north through desert (R#89) to Navajo Bridge in northern Arizona, west to Jacob Lake, south to visit North Rim of Grand Canyon, return north into Utah for night in Zion National Park. 6:00 A. M. to 7:00 P. M. 409 miles — total 3281 miles.
Across central Arizona approaching Flagstaff. The mountains are the San Francisco Peaks; 12,665 feet, highest in Arizona. Just before reaching them, we turn north on U. S. 89.
Mountains of various description on both sides of us as we drive north for the Grand Canyon. This is the western edge of the Navajo Reservation.

At Cameron, just north of the point where a road turns left to the South Rim of the Grand Canyon, we find a trading post, an inn, and a gas station. The children eagerly enter the trading post. Just beyond is the suspension bridge over the Little Colorado River. We cross it heading for the North Rim.

blocks.text: FIFTEENTH DAY — Saturday, July 4. From Afton to Grand Teton National Park, north through Yellowstone National Park (181 miles in Yellowstone), east from Yellow-stone to within 25 miles of Cody, Wyoming. 5:10 A. M. to 7:45 P. M. 337 miles — total 4235 miles.

Jackson, a colorful western town, is today given over to tourists, but in the early 1800's it was the gathering place of the mountainmen and trappers who first explored the region and who later led the settlers through the mountain passes.

Above - Leaving Afton in the early morning indeed (5:10 A. M.), we drive through the Grand Canyon of the Snake River where the road clings to the towering cliffs rising 1,000 feet above us, while over on the side churn the swift waters of the Snake River. Guard rails?...Needless luxuries!

blocks.text: The Tetons look like mountain ranges are expected to look - rugged, rocky, snow-capped, they rise 7,000 feet without foothills from the valley floor and loom, one after the other, for some forty miles. The highest summit, Grand Teton, shown center, is 13,766 feet above sea level. These mountains are said by geologists to be one of the finest examples of earth faulting to be seen anywhere.

blocks.text:
The Tetons were discovered about 1807–1808 by John Colter. Jackson's Hole was named in 1829 for David E. Jackson, a fur trader.
by John Colter.
Cindy stands on the shore of 14-miles-long Jackson Lake, which is fed by the Snake River, with the Tetons massed on one side and the opposite shore.
It is only six miles from the Grand Teton National Park to Yellowstone.

Old Faithful was considerable - we waited only about twenty minutes for the eruption.

blocks.text: Big bears, little bears...brown bears, black bears...we count a total of 22 as we drive through the Park. Visitors are definitely warned not to approach too close, for there have been instances of serious injury and even death from mishaps with bears.

blocks.text: The road has been anchored to the side of this cliff as we head through King-man Pass.
These high terraces at Mammoth Hot Springs were formed when hot water brought to the surface quantities of white mineral deposits in solution which gradually built up when the water cooled.
The main post office of the Park is at Mammoth Hot Springs...here also are the Park Headquarters. We have a quick bite to eat, and are on our way.

blocks.text: It's one thing to see snow on the mountain peaks and quite another to get your hands in it on the 4th of July. Here the children throw snow balls as we cross Dunraven Pass at 8,859 feet.

A pause on the shore of Yellowstone Lake as we definitely turn eastward for the first time on the trip. Yellowstone Lake is the highest lake for its size in the world, lying nearly a mile and a half above sea level, with a hundred miles of shore line and an area of 139 square miles.
Our first buffalo grazes unconcerned as traffic passes on the road two hundred feet away. No fences obstruct the movements of this huge animal.

After leaving Yellowstone Park by the East Entrance, we drive to within 25 miles of Cody before we find a place to spend the night. We occupy the right half of this cabin, for which we pay $10, the highest price for lodging on the entire trip. Before retiring we have a late snack at the restaurant adjoining the cabin. Here the children examine Indian curios on display.
Left - The finest spectacle of all in Yellowstone National Park – the Lower Falls, with a drop of 308 feet (twice the height of Niagara), and the Canyon of the Left. Enlarged from a 35mm negative.

blocks.text: SIXTEENTH DAY — Sunday, July 5. Into Cody, Wyo., east across Big Horn Mountains to Sheridan, Devils Tower National Monument, enter Black Hills, into South Dakota to Deadwood. 7:30 A. M. to 8:00 P. M. 426 miles – total 4661 miles.
As we approach Cody, we enter Shoshone Canyon and drive along the lake formed by Buffalo Bill Dam.

On top of Buffalo Bill Dam, said to be the second highest in the world. The road plummets down the 1,000 foot cliff to the Canyon floor, where the State Highway Commission maintains tractors to tow trucks and cars that stall on the way up.

blocks.text: We have forgotten entirely the very existence of the Big Horn Mountains ...but here they loom surprisingly high ahead of us as we travel across north-central Wyoming. We should have purchased gas at Greybull for we discover it is 58 miles between gas stations and we barely make it to the only available station atop the Big Horns.

One of the most thrilling drives of the whole trip as we climb Shell Canyon to the top of Big Horns on a road which repeatedly reverses itself by switch-backs and hairpin turns. For the only time on the trip the car overheats and we stop to let it cool off. The top of the Big Horns is a broad plateau where cattle graze. The descent (right) from the Big Horns is equally spectacular on a road cut from the side of the mountains with hardly a guardrail for protection. On exceptionally clear days, it is claimed the out-lines of the Black Hills are visible, 200 miles to the east.

blocks.text: Devils Tower, a National Monument, in northeast Wyoming rises 865 feet above the surrounding countryside. It has the appearanceance of a gigantic tree stump. Only a few persons have climbed the almost perpendicularly perpendicular sides.

SEVENTEENTH DAY — Monday, July 6. Tour of towns of Deadwood and Lead, south in Black Hills to Needles Highway, to Mt. Rushmore National Memorial, to Rapid City (Skyline Drive), due east to Wall, through the Badlands, across South Dakota to Chamberlain on Missouri River.

Deadwood tries hard to live up to its reputation as one of the riproaring towns of the gold rush days of 1876 when 25,000 prospectors and adventurers crowded into the area to seek their fortunes. Located in a deep gulch, houses crowd one upon another up the sides. It's a picturesque town which tries too self-conscious-ly to relive its past for the sake of the tourists' dollar.
OLD STYLE BAR

"Wild Bill" Hickok, reputed to have shot upwards of seventy men, has been built into a local celebrity. Kitty reads the inscription on his monument. In the saloon above, with the dramatic swaying effigy of "Wild Bill's" killer over the door, "Wild Bill" was shot in the back while holding black aces and eights in a poker game, ever since called a "dead-man's hand".
The sign over the door of this bar reads:""Them sufferf snak bit survived ferst"...for the benefit of the tourist.

blocks.text: Overlooking the town of Deadwood is Mount Moriah, or "Boothill" Cemetery, where lie buried some of the town's most famous characters. Behind the grave of "Wild Bill" is that of "Calamity Jane", whom the movies claim was his sweetheart, but records prove otherwise. Both graves have been surrounded with a fence to prevent souvenir hunters from chipping pieces from the tombstones.

A few miles up the gulch from Deadwood is Lead (pronounced Leed), said to have been the wild-west, wide-open town in the world 75 years ago. Today it is the home of the Homestead Mine, the largest and richest gold mine in America. Inside the mine are 100 miles of railroad, 27 levels of tunnel, and the world's fastest-dropping elevators. Some of the tunnels extend 5,000 feet into the ground to approximately sea level. At full production more than 1,500,000 tons of ore are mined annually.

From Lead, we head south through the Black Hills for the Needles Highway and Mount Rushmore while we listen to the Arthur Godfrey Show on the car radio. The Black Hills, "Land of the Sioux," are of course not "hills" at all, but mountains which rise to 7,242 feet at Harney Peak. They are being exploited to the utmost as a tourist attraction. At left, the road has been tunneled through solid rock. Right, Sylvan Lake, more than a mile above sea level.

blocks.text: More than 1,600 buffalo are protected and are actually on the increase in the State Game Preserve.
In the distance is Mount Rushmore while the road is given a needless over-and-under construction to thrill the tourist.

Mount Rushmore National Memorial
Sculptured between 1927 and 1941 by the late Gutzon Borglum.
The carved mountain is of granite.
The figures attachea a maximum elevation of over six hundred feet higher than the elevation (528 feet) at this point. The sculptured busts are proportionate to the men as feet high.
Washington's head measures go 90 feet, his eyes top to chin - 16 inches and nose measure 7 inch wide. The eye is made of copper.
U.S. Department of the Interior
National Park Service

At the restaurant and curio store at the base of Mount Rushmore, the sign gives a brief his-tory of the creation of the National Memorial. The Indian, wearing a too obvious toupee, is the center of considerable interest.

blocks.text: Indian children tending sheep in the desert as we approach Navajo Bridge. As soon as they saw we wanted to take their pictures, the one on the left began to shout, "Mon-ey, mon-ey"; and the one on the right cried, "Dol-ar, dol-ar". We understood what they wanted, and both seemed pleased to settle for 25¢ which Cindy is here passing to them.

blocks.text: Mount Rushmore National Memorial, the “Shrine of Democracy”, commemorates four great Americans – Washington, Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt and Lincoln. To gain an idea of the size of this memorial, the head of Washington measures 60 feet from its top to the chin. The memorial has never been finished. Gutzon Borglum, the sculptor, died in 1941 and the National Park Service feels that his work should remain as he left it.

blocks.text:
It could happen only in America. The drug store at Wall,
a town of a few hundred souls on the edge of the Dakota
Badlands, began to advertise free ice water to tourists
for a radius of 500 miles. Today everyone seems to take
time out to stop there, so that it has become necessary
to employ 40 to 50 clerks to handle the business. This
success story has been written up in a number of maga-
zines with national circulation. The nature of this phe-
nomenal growth is disclosed in the inside where one addi-
tion after another has been made without any apparent
sense of order or planning.
THE ICE WATER DRUG STORE
In the rear of the drug store props are provided free for visiting photographers.

The Badlands of South Dakota embrace more than 150,000 acres of weird, exotic scenery. Erosion has hewn sedimentary deposits from what was once a great salt sea into fantastic shapes, some rising more than 500 feet. It is estimated this process has required more than 60 million years. The region has variously been described as "Hell with the fires out" and an area where "communion with what man often calls 'God' is inevitable".

blocks.text: Across South Dakota where the land rises and falls like huge swells of the ocean and where towns are far apart and the feeling is one of great loneliness. We eat where we can find a small town, Ray's Cafe being in Belvidere where there are few trees and little of beauty. Darkness overtakes us...and only the car radio and our own conversation offset an uneasiness caused by the abounding quietness and the limitless space. We finally find a tourist home for the night in Chamberlain on the banks of the Missouri River.

EIGHTEENTH DAY — Tuesday, July 7. Chamberlain to Mitchell, to Sioux Falls, into Minnesota to Preston, through northeast corner of Iowa, enter Wisconsin across Mississippi River at Prairie du Chien, to Lancaster, Wisconsin for night. 7:30 A. M. to 8:15 P. M. 523 miles — total 5549 miles.

Cindy cleans the windshield after a heavy electric storm during the night. We drive back through Chamberlain to get a picture of the bridge over the Missouri River which we had crossed the night before. At breakfast in the town an old settler told us the story o f an eastern family which had come to the section, made a fortune in cattle, but had to return east because they couldn't stand the loneliness.

Darkness overtakes us...and only the car radio and our own conversation offset an uneasiness caused by the abounding quietness and the limitless space. We finally find a tourist home for the night in Chamberlain on the banks of the Missouri River.

EIGHTEENTH DAY — Tuesday, July 7. Chamberlain to Mitchell, to Sioux Falls, into Minnesota to Preston, through northeast corner of Iowa, enter Wisconsin across Mississippi River at Prairie du Chien, to Lancaster, Wisconsin for night. 7:30 A. M. to 8:15 P. M. 523 miles — total 5549 miles.

Cindy cleans the windshield after a heavy electric storm during the night. We drive back through Chamberlain to get a picture of the bridge over the Missouri River which we had crossed the night before. At breakfast in the town an old settler told us the story o f an eastern family which had come to the section, made a fortune in cattle, but had to return east because they couldn't stand the loneliness.

blocks.text: WINNIESHIK COUNTY
We cut south from Minnesota to traverse the northeastern corner of Iowa....where "the tall corn grows".
This is exceedingly rich farming country in the valley of the Mississippi River. The land is rolling and the farms and farm buildings stand favorable comparison with our own Lancaster County.

Across the Mississippi River to Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin, originally a stop-over for early fur traders... fail to secure accommodations and drive after dark as far as Lancaster where we locate a motel at the south-end edge of the town. After unloading our bags, we drive back into the town for a late supper. The children are intrigued by our presence in another Lancaster.

blocks.text: NINETEENTH DAY — Wednesday, July 8. Lancaster, Wisconsin to Sterling, Ill (visit Kitty's relatives), to Lincoln Highway (R#30), to Aurora, pass south of Chicago, into Indiana as far as Columbia City. 8:45 A. M. to 8:00 P.M. 360 miles — total 5909 miles.
DRIVE CAREFULLY IN SCHOOL ZONES.
Kathy stands alongside the sign at the edge of Lancaster, Wisconsin.
The new, modern and comfortable motel at Lancaster, Wisconsin.
The rich, black farmlands of Illinois. We spend several hours in Sterling visiting some of Kitty's relatives whose ancestors were almost wiped out by a cholera epidemic.
Into Indiana as far as Columbia City. The children are in good spirits. Although it is almost 600 miles, we decide to try for home the next day.

blocks.text: TWENTIETH DAY - Thursday, July 9. Decide to try for home; Columbia City to Fort Wayne, across Ohio via Van Wert, Bucyrus, Wooster, Canton, to Pennsylvania Turnpike, across Turnpike to Harrisburg-East exit, to Lancaster and home. To 11:30 P. M. 577 miles - total 6489 miles.
OHIO STATE LINE.
Forty three miles through Indiana, including Fort Wayne, and we reach the western border of Ohio. We are making excellent time. The land, like that of Illinois, is extremely flat.

Gordon samples some of the Swiss cheese made in eastern Ohio. It tastes better than Gor-don's expression indicates. We run into a bottleneck of traffic in eastern Ohio as we approach the entrance to the Pennsylvania Turnpike because the state roads of Ohio were never built to handle so great a volume of trucks and automobiles.

blocks.text: The massive, bright-hued Vermilion Cliffs of northern Arizona. Between us and the Cliffs the winding Colorado has cut a deep canyon which we cross at Navajo Bridge.

blocks.text: Philadelphia

It is good to be home again after 20 days of traveling and after having covered almost 6,500 miles. Louise greets us enthusiastically the next morning when we pick her up at Grandfather and Grandmother Kreider's home.

blocks.text: Ruins of an ancient dwelling in the desert, with the Vermillion Cliffs in the background. Our road lies to the left, within a half mile of the crossing of the Colorado River, which is as yet not visible.

The spectacular Navajo Bridge across the Colorado River at a height of 467 feet, with a span of 616 feet, the only crossing of the Colorado in a thousand miles. So remote is this region that considerable sections to the northeast are still unexplored.

Just beyond the Bridge at Mar-ble Canyon we stop for gas at a filling station and restau-rant, the only accommodations for miles, and we ask the attendan-t what he does for entertainment. His reply is he goes to Flagstaff occasion-ally on a Saturday night, which is 125 miles away.

Following the Vermilion Cliffs for perhaps 25 miles.

With beautiful white clouds hovering overhead, we leave the valley of the Vermilion Cliffs and begin a climb to the plateau through which the Colorado River has cut the tremendous swath we call the Grand Canyon.
In the valley there is desert - here on the plateau we drive through forests of stately ponderosa pine.
A brief stop at Jacob Lake, where we fill our jug with ice cubes, before heading due south for 44 miles to the North Rim of the Grand Canyon.

blocks.text: COLORADO

Left - About to enter Grand Canyon National Park,
an area of 1009 square miles, containing half of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River.
Right - The road leads us through forests of dense aspens, which remind us of white birch at home. So many deer are seen the children lose track of their count.

Left - the Lodge located on the very rim of the Canyon.
The Lodgedodgee locclocceonated oocconooned on the v vy gery riyrm riimm off the CCanyhonyo.. .
